componenttext: Your next question is from Mike Baker from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I will ask about what you're saying Hispanic markets, I know you've talked about some of the original trends, but there's been some concern that some Hispanic markets might not be performing as well. Any thing to call out there in terms of your same-store
componenttext: I will ask about what you're saying Hispanic markets, I know you've talked about some of the original trends, but there's been some concern that some Hispanic markets might not be performing as well. Any thing to call out there in terms of your same-store sales?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Mike, we track and analyze the performance of our stores based upon various different demographic factors. And obviously, that includes looking at Hispanic markets, and the answer is no. We have not seen an issue in those markets.
componenttext: Mike, we track and analyze the performance of our stores based upon various different demographic factors. And obviously, that includes looking at Hispanic markets, and the answer is no. We have not seen an issue in those markets.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. If I could ask one more. I was curious of the promotional environment. Some of the department stores lowered their inventories, the gross margins were lower though, which speaks to being promotional. Obviously, you guys did well, but
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. If I could ask one more. I was curious of the promotional environment. Some of the department stores lowered their inventories, the gross margins were lower though, which speaks to being promotional. Obviously, you guys did well, but I'm wondering if you had any comments on the promotional environment from some of your competitors.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. Although the inventory levels were down, the promotional environment continue to be very aggressive. And actually, we just consider that is the way to do business now. But that's going to continue as we go forward for back-to-school and for holiday.
componenttext: Sure. Although the inventory levels were down, the promotional environment continue to be very aggressive. And actually, we just consider that is the way to do business now. But that's going to continue as we go forward for back-to-school and for holiday.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Omar Saad from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Your next question is from Omar Saad from Evercore ISI.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about marketing. How you guys are evolving your marketing strategies in this digital era? Are you using new techniques because the traffic and the conference were, obviously, quite excellent and kind of what's happening out there the rest
componenttext: I wanted to ask about marketing. How you guys are evolving your marketing strategies in this digital era? Are you using new techniques because the traffic and the conference were, obviously, quite excellent and kind of what's happening out there the rest of the retail, I wonder if you can point to some new media strategies that might be working for you.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: So Omar, it's Michael O'Sullivan. I would say that our marketing strategy, marketing message, marketing programs remain fairly consistent. The message in those marketing programs is that we offer great values. And it's really the great values, but I think
componenttext: So Omar, it's Michael O'Sullivan. I would say that our marketing strategy, marketing message, marketing programs remain fairly consistent. The message in those marketing programs is that we offer great values. And it's really the great values, but I think, have driven our trend and will continue to buy back trend rather than the marketing programs. Now within your question, you mentioned sort of new marketing techniques, it is true. We're absolutely experimenting and expanding nontraditional forms of marketing. But I'd stop short of saying that those are really making a significant contribution to our trend. They're helpful, but then works pretty well driving our business.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Lorraine Hutchinson from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question is from Lorraine Hutchinson from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Can you provide some information around comp metrics? Was traffic positive? What did you see in ticket? And anything else that you could share to help us get a feel for how you drove that was plus 4%?
componenttext: Can you provide some information around comp metrics? Was traffic positive? What did you see in ticket? And anything else that you could share to help us get a feel for how you drove that was plus 4%?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure, Lorraine. As we mentioned in our prepared remarks, the 4% comp was driven by higher traffic and an increase in the size of the average basket. Proportionately, traffic contributed more than the basket. The higher basket was driven by an increase in
componenttext: Sure, Lorraine. As we mentioned in our prepared remarks, the 4% comp was driven by higher traffic and an increase in the size of the average basket. Proportionately, traffic contributed more than the basket. The higher basket was driven by an increase in more units. AUR was down just slightly due to the mix of business.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Paul Lejuez from Citi.
componenttext: Your next question is from Paul Lejuez from Citi.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, Home business, can you just comment on how Home performed during the quarter? And also, curious, what percent of your business is Home right now in Ross versus dd's? And where do you see that going over time?
componenttext: Well, Home business, can you just comment on how Home performed during the quarter? And also, curious, what percent of your business is Home right now in Ross versus dd's? And where do you see that going over time?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. Home outperformed the company. It continues to be a strong business for us as it is for many people. In terms of our total percent to company...
componenttext: Sure. Home outperformed the company. It continues to be a strong business for us as it is for many people. In terms of our total percent to company...

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul, the breakout within Ross and dd's, we wouldn't break that out separately on a total basis. It's upward 20% of the business is Home, 25%, it's about a quarter.
componenttext: Yes, Paul, the breakout within Ross and dd's, we wouldn't break that out separately on a total basis. It's upward 20% of the business is Home, 25%, it's about a quarter.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Got you. Curious, have you guys started thinking about store growth for Ross versus dd's next year? I'm just curious how far away are we from may be seeing the growth start to skew more towards dd's versus Ross? Or is that very far often to be into the fu
componenttext: Got you. Curious, have you guys started thinking about store growth for Ross versus dd's next year? I'm just curious how far away are we from may be seeing the growth start to skew more towards dd's versus Ross? Or is that very far often to be into the future?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We'll comment more at the end of the year on our specific plans for 2018. But I think for planning purposes, you can assume that our store openings will be pretty much in line with where they've been the last couple of years, 80 to 90 new stores, approxim
componenttext: We'll comment more at the end of the year on our specific plans for 2018. But I think for planning purposes, you can assume that our store openings will be pretty much in line with where they've been the last couple of years, 80 to 90 new stores, approximately 20 to 25 of those being dd's and the rest being Ross. I wouldn't expect a significant change in that over the next couple of years.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Laura Champine from Roe Equity Research.
componenttext: Your next question is from Laura Champine from Roe Equity Research.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: You just put up a very strong comp on a 2-year basis and the guidance for next quarter's comp is perhaps even better, implies that you could do even better in 8% to 9% comp on a 2-year basis. Is your confidence in continuing to grow the comp next quarter,
componenttext: You just put up a very strong comp on a 2-year basis and the guidance for next quarter's comp is perhaps even better, implies that you could do even better in 8% to 9% comp on a 2-year basis. Is your confidence in continuing to grow the comp next quarter, the one that we're currently in, is that driven by trends you're seeing today? Or what else may you be factoring into that assumption?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure, Laura. While we do face our most challenging prior year comparisons in Q3, it's clear to us that the consumer continues to favor retailers that offer compelling value. And we think that bodes well for us going into the third quarter.
componenttext: Sure, Laura. While we do face our most challenging prior year comparisons in Q3, it's clear to us that the consumer continues to favor retailers that offer compelling value. And we think that bodes well for us going into the third quarter.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Oliver Chen from Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Your next question is from Oliver Chen from Cowen and Company.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We had a question related to inventory. It's been extremely well managed throughout the years. What are your thoughts for what's next? And it feels like your stores could even have more stuff and there's nice opportunities in new categories. So just a que
componenttext: We had a question related to inventory. It's been extremely well managed throughout the years. What are your thoughts for what's next? And it feels like your stores could even have more stuff and there's nice opportunities in new categories. So just a question about different priorities with inventory management and what you can do to potentially even maximize the existing space you have. And then longer term, I was just curious about what's in your mindset in terms of your corporate strategies and what you're thinking about with digital at large over the next 5 years?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Oliver, on the inventory question, so we've gone through a period of 7 to 8 years of reduction. Our total inventory is down over 40% over the last number of years. So as we look at it going forward, we're comfortable operating at our current levels. Those
componenttext: Oliver, on the inventory question, so we've gone through a period of 7 to 8 years of reduction. Our total inventory is down over 40% over the last number of years. So as we look at it going forward, we're comfortable operating at our current levels. Those reductions, obviously, have contributed to significant margin improvements, but we're in very late innings of those reductions and are comfortable at the current level.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And then on your question about digital, Oliver, if I break into -- first of all marketing, we are -- over the last 5 to 8 years, we've gone from building really nothing on sort of nontraditional digital marketing, so to speak, to a significant chunk of o
componenttext: And then on your question about digital, Oliver, if I break into -- first of all marketing, we are -- over the last 5 to 8 years, we've gone from building really nothing on sort of nontraditional digital marketing, so to speak, to a significant chunk of our marketing budget now goes into those media, and we're pretty happy with the results. A lot of that space is still evolving, so I think we have additional things to learn, but I would be surprised if we didn't further increase our marketing mix in that direction over time. And then separately, I don't think it is what you're getting at separately digital sort of e-commerce, we have no plans to pursue -- we haven't changed our view, we've no plans to pursue e-commerce at this point.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. And are your inventories too lean because they're so tight? I'm just curious where you'll reach a point you can do more with more?
componenttext: Okay. And are your inventories too lean because they're so tight? I'm just curious where you'll reach a point you can do more with more?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Obviously, we watch very closely our inventory turns in the stores. And given our ability to continue to drive comp with a 4% comp in this past quarter on top of 4% last year, we feel pretty good. I think, we're capturing the business that's out there. No
componenttext: Obviously, we watch very closely our inventory turns in the stores. And given our ability to continue to drive comp with a 4% comp in this past quarter on top of 4% last year, we feel pretty good. I think, we're capturing the business that's out there. Now, Obviously, there's always -- we always look at the mix of businesses and some businesses are growing more rapidly, and we might be more aggressive on inventory, but that's where your business, business thing rather than overall.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Michael Binetti from UBS.
componenttext: Your next question is from Michael Binetti from UBS.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: So just on your comments that the consumer is using value is the answer to the focus for third quarter and how you get to the comp with the difficult comparison. Maybe you can help us with some of the dimensionality on a couple of things. First off, can I
componenttext: So just on your comments that the consumer is using value is the answer to the focus for third quarter and how you get to the comp with the difficult comparison. Maybe you can help us with some of the dimensionality on a couple of things. First off, can I assume that the plan is to deliver value and that the comp assumes strong traffic? And maybe some AUR pressure than we saw last quarter? And then maybe some help on how to think about gross margin versus SG&A. Are you willing to take some more merchandise margin pressure than we've seen in recent quarters to help you anniversary that big comp?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, Michael. On the comp, if we think about the components between first and second quarter and our current trends in the second quarter, the performance was fairly broad, broad based across merchandise division and regions. So we feel confident that the
componenttext: Yes, Michael. On the comp, if we think about the components between first and second quarter and our current trends in the second quarter, the performance was fairly broad, broad based across merchandise division and regions. So we feel confident that the consumers responding to value, and we feel good about our inventory entering the third quarter.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And maybe I could ask you just a follow-up on Lorraine's question from earlier. A little bit more on the AUR. What is driving the AUR in your business today? Is it a mixed function? And then same question on what -- you had some nice comments on the units
componenttext: And maybe I could ask you just a follow-up on Lorraine's question from earlier. A little bit more on the AUR. What is driving the AUR in your business today? Is it a mixed function? And then same question on what -- you had some nice comments on the units per transaction to, what other categories that are helping you guys drive the consumer to pick up a couple extra items and growing basket the basket?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, on AUR, AUR has been relatively flat over the last several years. They're down slightly. Again, that's mix-related based on what's driving the business. I'd answer your question on the basket, if I go to the merchandising areas, all major mer
componenttext: Yes. I mean, on AUR, AUR has been relatively flat over the last several years. They're down slightly. Again, that's mix-related based on what's driving the business. I'd answer your question on the basket, if I go to the merchandising areas, all major merchandising areas were positive during the quarter as well as merchandise region. We did call out shoes during the quarter. Overall, non-apparel during the second quarter outperformed apparel. So really good about the trends, and believe we are set up well for a strong back half.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And Mike, I think the merchants have been able to deliver value to the customers. So in this promotional environment where value moves a lot, one of the critical thing is for merchant understand the value as they move and to respond appropriately. And so
componenttext: And Mike, I think the merchants have been able to deliver value to the customers. So in this promotional environment where value moves a lot, one of the critical thing is for merchant understand the value as they move and to respond appropriately. And so with that comes potentially mix issues, based off of what's available, based off what the customers want. But really understanding that movement of value as we move along, and that's really recognizing how promotional it is and how it's going to remain that way, I think is a critical part of what merchants do everyday and has added to our broad-based success in merchandise categories in Q2.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I guess, my question is more -- you've seen the bogey man, the 7-comp coming for a long time, you knew about a year ago. So is it the strategy here is we know values working and the strategy for long time has been to buy up per unit, so we'll see as the t
componenttext: I guess, my question is more -- you've seen the bogey man, the 7-comp coming for a long time, you knew about a year ago. So is it the strategy here is we know values working and the strategy for long time has been to buy up per unit, so we'll see as the traffic component of the comp is what accelerates in the 2-year to help you guys lap that. Is that what we should expect to be?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, a couple of things, Michael. Our outlook for the back half has not changed from the beginning of the year. So again, why we feel really good, that's the way we plan to business. If you look at our -- the way we guided the back half, it hasn't change
componenttext: Well, a couple of things, Michael. Our outlook for the back half has not changed from the beginning of the year. So again, why we feel really good, that's the way we plan to business. If you look at our -- the way we guided the back half, it hasn't changed. The upside to the year was based on the outperformance in the second quarter, so the $0.06 that we added to the high end of the range for the year was all based on second quarter performance.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Simeon Siegel from Nomura Instinet.
componenttext: Your next question is from Simeon Siegel from Nomura Instinet.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think you spoke to the merch margins. Any color you could share on the 3 and 4Q gross margins embedded within your guides? And then can you quantify the concentration of your top vendors within revenues at this time, and has that changed at all?
componenttext: I think you spoke to the merch margins. Any color you could share on the 3 and 4Q gross margins embedded within your guides? And then can you quantify the concentration of your top vendors within revenues at this time, and has that changed at all?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: In terms of specific guidance in Q3 and Q4, the only guidance that we gave was my comment on merch margins and the comparisons versus last year, so we wouldn't give any further detail on that on the back half margin.
componenttext: In terms of specific guidance in Q3 and Q4, the only guidance that we gave was my comment on merch margins and the comparisons versus last year, so we wouldn't give any further detail on that on the back half margin.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And then on the vendor base, no real changes to that. As you know, we have a very large, diverse and fragmented vendor base with lots of vendors. And from time to time, our different vendors become more or less important, but no single vendor is particula
componenttext: And then on the vendor base, no real changes to that. As you know, we have a very large, diverse and fragmented vendor base with lots of vendors. And from time to time, our different vendors become more or less important, but no single vendor is particularly important in the overall mix.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Kimberly Greenberger from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question is from Kimberly Greenberger from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask, the third quarter comp guidance of plus 1% to 2%, is it fair to assume or could we assume that the business is running in that range so far here in the third quarter? And then secondarily, it looks like there were a number of going out of
componenttext: I wanted to ask, the third quarter comp guidance of plus 1% to 2%, is it fair to assume or could we assume that the business is running in that range so far here in the third quarter? And then secondarily, it looks like there were a number of going out of business sales during the second quarter, particularly among department stores. I know the environment is tough and seems to be just getting tougher every year, but Ross seems to sail right on through that undisrupted. I just wanted to know if there was any disruption at all in stores that were new those store closings. Or did you really just not see it at all? Obviously, we're not seeing any impact in the total company comp, but you, obviously, have more granular insight.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Hi, Kimberly, we wouldn't comment on third quarter trends. On the store closures, what we're seeing is stores that are located close to the stores during liquidation had a slight negative impact and then post-closure, slight positive impact. That said, th
componenttext: Hi, Kimberly, we wouldn't comment on third quarter trends. On the store closures, what we're seeing is stores that are located close to the stores during liquidation had a slight negative impact and then post-closure, slight positive impact. That said, the impact to the chain is not material giving on a base of close to 1,600 stores.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Bob Drbul from Guggenheim.
componenttext: Your next question is from Bob Drbul from Guggenheim.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Two questions. I was wondering if you could comment on how your business performed in California. I think there was a bit of a drag in the first quarter, I think largely weather. And I was also wondering if you might just comment on the women's business a
componenttext: Two questions. I was wondering if you could comment on how your business performed in California. I think there was a bit of a drag in the first quarter, I think largely weather. And I was also wondering if you might just comment on the women's business and how that's been performing for you.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: On regional performance, all of our major markets, California, Texas, Florida were relatively in line with the chain average in the second quarter.
componenttext: On regional performance, all of our major markets, California, Texas, Florida were relatively in line with the chain average in the second quarter.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And in terms of ladies' business, ladies', once again, posted a positive gain in the quarter.
componenttext: And in terms of ladies' business, ladies', once again, posted a positive gain in the quarter.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Dana Telsey from Telsey Group.
componenttext: Your next question is from Dana Telsey from Telsey Group.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: As you think about wages and shrink, any update on those 2 components and game plan for the second half of the year? And then on dd's, and that strong performance in sales and operating income, what are the key drivers there? And has anything changed in t
componenttext: As you think about wages and shrink, any update on those 2 components and game plan for the second half of the year? And then on dd's, and that strong performance in sales and operating income, what are the key drivers there? And has anything changed in that business?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure, Dana, on shrink and wage question, no changes are expected in shrink trends. We continue to operate at very low levels, record levels for us, and we typically take our physical inventory in the third quarter, so we'll have an update, if any, change
componenttext: Sure, Dana, on shrink and wage question, no changes are expected in shrink trends. We continue to operate at very low levels, record levels for us, and we typically take our physical inventory in the third quarter, so we'll have an update, if any, change for that trend in Q3. On wages, we do expect the wage pressure to abate somewhat in the second half as we're now anniversary-ing the most recent company-wide wage increases that took place in last year's second quarter. As a reminder, our guidance for SG&A, the leverage point remains at about 3% for us for the year.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And Dana, your question about dd's, as Barbara mentioned in her remarks, we were pleased with dd's' strong performance in terms of sales and operating profit in the second quarter.  dd's eventually continued at it has over the several quarters, it's good
componenttext: And Dana, your question about dd's, as Barbara mentioned in her remarks, we were pleased with dd's' strong performance in terms of sales and operating profit in the second quarter.  dd's eventually continued at it has over the several quarters, it's good results. In terms of what's driving that, frankly, it's similar to many of the other things that we talked about on this call so far, in particular, the dd's customer is responding well to the values that we're offering.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Lindsay Drucker Mann from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question is from Lindsay Drucker Mann from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I was hoping -- could you tell us what proportion of your sales come from credit cards? And secondly, on the SG&A piece, well the leverage point on a 4-comp, you leveraged operating margins pretty nicely, SG&A growth was lower than what we had seen in 1Q,
componenttext: I was hoping -- could you tell us what proportion of your sales come from credit cards? And secondly, on the SG&A piece, well the leverage point on a 4-comp, you leveraged operating margins pretty nicely, SG&A growth was lower than what we had seen in 1Q, and sorry if I missed this, but can you talk about the rate of SG&A increase in 2Q being lower versus 1Q and what we should be thinking about for the back half?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. On your question on credit, it's about 1/3 of our business, Lindsay. And then on the SG&A leverage, as we mentioned in the call, we had 25 basis points of leverage on the 4-comp. 20 of that 25 was related to a nonrecurring legal matter. So base line
componenttext: Sure. On your question on credit, it's about 1/3 of our business, Lindsay. And then on the SG&A leverage, as we mentioned in the call, we had 25 basis points of leverage on the 4-comp. 20 of that 25 was related to a nonrecurring legal matter. So base line, 5 basis points of leverage. As I mentioned on wages in the back half, we should expect less leverage, so at a 1 to 2 comp, there may be some deleverage, but at 3, we should get leverage.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And then can you comment on how your new stores are performing, new store productivity, proceeds of your new openings for Ross and dd's relative to what you have seen in last year or years past?
componenttext: Okay, got it. And then can you comment on how your new stores are performing, new store productivity, proceeds of your new openings for Ross and dd's relative to what you have seen in last year or years past?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. So as we mentioned in the past, our new store productivity has come down since we entered the Midwest in 2011 and also our growth at dd's chain has impacted overall productivity. I would say though in the last couple of years, it's been very steady
componenttext: Sure. So as we mentioned in the past, our new store productivity has come down since we entered the Midwest in 2011 and also our growth at dd's chain has impacted overall productivity. I would say though in the last couple of years, it's been very steady at/or above our expectations. Overall Ross new stores about 60% to 65% of the chain average, and then tends to comp faster in the first couple of years.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Brian Tunick from RBC.
componenttext: Your next question is from Brian Tunick from RBC.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I guess, 2 or 3 questions. Number one, I know you guys don't manage to a packaway number per se, but obviously, there's been a lot of concern given what the vendors have been talking about. So just curious if you can maybe talk about the buying staff, wha
componenttext: I guess, 2 or 3 questions. Number one, I know you guys don't manage to a packaway number per se, but obviously, there's been a lot of concern given what the vendors have been talking about. So just curious if you can maybe talk about the buying staff, what you've been doing there, maybe turn over in your top I think [indiscernible] has 10 vendors. But just curious more about how packaway could continue to run at these levels given what the vendors seem to be saying. Second question would be may be from a store growth runway and returns you're seeing on the new stores, at what point would you guys consider a new concept like Home, which seem to something people are moving into? And then thirdly, on freight contracts, Mike, just curious, what's the length of the contracts and how's your best viewpoint going into next year?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I'll start in the last one, because that's probably [indiscernible]. On freight, we expect there to be a headwind for the rest of the year. Contracts vary. We have pretty good viewpoint for the rest of the year, and we expect to continue to be a headwind.
componenttext: I'll start in the last one, because that's probably [indiscernible]. On freight, we expect there to be a headwind for the rest of the year. Contracts vary. We have pretty good viewpoint for the rest of the year, and we expect to continue to be a headwind. And then going into the next year, we'll talk more about that on the year-end conference call.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I'll take the second question, and maybe Barbara will take the first, so we'll work in reverse. So how long the store growth runway. We put out there a store potential number of 2,500 stores, and that's 2,000 Ross, 500 dd's, we're only at 1,670. We've got
componenttext: I'll take the second question, and maybe Barbara will take the first, so we'll work in reverse. So how long the store growth runway. We put out there a store potential number of 2,500 stores, and that's 2,000 Ross, 500 dd's, we're only at 1,670. We've got many years to go before we hit that number. You've mentioned Home specifically and moving into, I guess, the separate Home concept. We're very excited about Home. Our Home businesses has been one of our strong performing businesses for a number of years, but we feel very happy with our ability to really go off after that within our existing concepts and really, sort of continue to grow that business within Ross and dd's rather than a separate store concept.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017

componenttext: And as it pertains to packaway, the packaway number fluctuate based on availability in the market and the way the merchant see it, and there has been -- there's been plenty of branded bargains in the marketplace. So there's availability. I know there isn't a lot of talk about different vendors having different strategies, but vendor strategies fluctuate over time and net-net, there are a lot of goods in the marketplace and a lot of branded goods. And so we feel pretty good about the position that we're in and the content that we have.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Ross Stores Second Quarter 2017 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]Before we get started, on behalf of Ross Stores, I would like to note that the comments made on this call will contain forward-lo
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to the Ross Stores Second Quarter 2017 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]
Before we get started, on behalf of Ross Stores, I would like to note that the comments made on this call will contain forward-looking statements regarding expectations about future growth and financial results, including sales and earnings forecasts and other matters that are based on the company's current forecast of aspects of its future business. These forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from historical performance or current expectations. Risk factors are included in today's press release and the company's fiscal 2016 Form 10-K and fiscal 2017 Form 10-Q and 8-Ks on file with the SEC.
Now, I'd like to turn the call over to Barbara Rentler, Chief Executive Officer.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon.Joining me on our call today are Michael Balmuth, Executive Chairman; Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Executive Vice President, Financ
componenttext:
Good afternoon.
Joining me on our call today are Michael Balmuth, Executive Chairman; Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Executive Vice President, Finance and Legal; Michael Hartshorn, Group Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Connie Kao, Vice President, Investor Relations.
We will begin our call today with a review of our second quarter and year-to-date performance, followed by our outlook for the remainder of the year. Afterwards, we'll be happy to respond to any questions you may have.
As noted in today's press release, we are pleased with the better-than-expected growth we delivered in both sales and earnings in the second quarter, especially given our challenging multiyear comparisons and today's volatile retail climate. Earnings per share for the period were $0.82, up 15% on top of a 13% increase last year. Net earnings for the second quarter grew to $317 million compared to $282 million for the same period last year. Sales rose 8% to $3,432,000,000 with comparable store sales up 4% on top of a 4% gain in the prior year. Operating margin of 14.9% for the quarter outperformed our projections mainly due to a combination of higher merchandise margins and leverage on our above-planned sales.
For the first 6 months of fiscal 2017, earnings per share were $1.64, up 14% on top of a 9% increase in the prior year. Net earnings were $638 million, up from $573 million in last year's growth path. Sales year-to-date rose 7% to $6.738 billion with comparable store sales up 4% versus a 3% gain in the same period last year. 
Sales trends during the quarter were broad-based across all major geographic regions and merchandise category. The midwest and southeast were the strongest regions while shoes was the best performing merchandise category at Ross. dd's DISCOUNTS also posted strong better-than-expected gains in both sales and operating profits for the quarter.
As we ended the second quarter, total consolidated inventories were up 3% compared to the prior year, with average in-store inventories up slightly. Packaway as a percent of total inventories was 46% compared to 47% at this time last year.
Turning to expansion programs. We opened 21 new Ross and 7 dd's DISCOUNTS locations in the second quarter. For the 2017 fiscal year, we continue to plan for a total of about 70 new Ross and 20 dd's DISCOUNTS locations. As usual, these numbers do not reflect our plans to close or relocate a handful of stores.
Now, Michael Hartshorn will provide further color on our second quarter results and details on our second half guidance.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Barbara.Let's start with our second quarter results. Our 4% comparable store sales gain was driven by increases in both traffic and the size of the average basket. As mentioned earlier, second quarter operating margin outperformed our project
componenttext:
Thank you, Barbara.
Let's start with our second quarter results. Our 4% comparable store sales gain was driven by increases in both traffic and the size of the average basket. As mentioned earlier, second quarter operating margin outperformed our projections, increasing 50 basis points to 14.9% compared to 14.4% last year.
Cost of goods sold for the second quarter improved 25 basis points driven by a better-than-expected 35 basis point increase in merchandise margin, 20 basis points in lower occupancy costs and distribution expenses that were lower by 10 basis points. These gains were partially offset by a 25 basis point increase in freight costs, along with 15 basis points of higher buying costs.
Selling, general and administrative expenses during the period were lower by 25 basis points. This improvement includes a nonrecurring benefit of approximately 20 basis points from legal-related costs.
During the quarter, we repurchased 3.6 million shares of common stock for a total purchase price of $215 million. Year-to-date, we have bought back a total of 6.9 million shares for an aggregate price of $430 million. As planned, we expect to buy back a total of $875 million in stock for the year under the 2-year $1.75 billion stock repurchase program approved by our Board of Directors in February of this year.
Let's turn now to our second half guidance. For the third quarter ending October 28, 2017, same-store sales are forecast to increase 1% to 2% on top of a robust 7% gain last year, with earnings per share projected to be in the range of $0.64 to $0.67 versus $0.62 in last year's third quarter.
For the fourth quarter ending February 3, 2018, we are also planning same-store sales to be up 1% to 2% on top of a solid 4% gain last year, with earnings per share projected to be $0.88 to $0.92 compared to $0.77 last year. This includes an approximate benefit of $0.08 due to the 53rd week.
Now, I'll provide some additional operating statement assumptions for the third quarter EPS target. Total sales are projected to grow 4% to 5%. We're planning to add 30 new Ross and 10 dd's DISCOUNTS locations during the period. Operating margin is projected to be in the range of 12.4% to 12.6% versus 12.6% in the prior year. Net interest expense is estimated to be about $2.5 million. Our tax rate is planned at approximately 37% to 38%. And we expect average diluted shares outstanding to be about 384 million. As noted in today's press release, based on our results for the first 6 months as well as our second half forecast, we now are projecting earnings per share for the full year on a 53-week basis to increase 12% to 14% to $3.16 to $3.23 on top of a 13% gain in fiscal 2016.
Now, I'll turn the call back to Barbara for closing comments.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael.Once again, we are pleased with the better-than-expected sales and earnings gains we delivered for both the second quarter and the first half of the year. These results were driven by our ongoing ability to offer compelling bargains t
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael.
Once again, we are pleased with the better-than-expected sales and earnings gains we delivered for both the second quarter and the first half of the year. These results were driven by our ongoing ability to offer compelling bargains to today's value-oriented consumer.
Looking ahead to the second half, we realize that we face our most challenging prior year comparisons and a volatile retail backdrop. So while we hope to do better, we believe it is prudent to maintain a somewhat cautious outlook for the balance of this year, which is reflected in our guidance.
Nevertheless, over the longer-term, we are very confident in our ability to offer customers outstanding value throughout our stores. This will always be our top priority as it has proven to be the most crucial driver in consistently delivering solid results in both sales and earnings.
At this point, we'd like to open up the call and respond to any questions you may have.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Michael, I want to ask you about the merch margin line. You guided it flat to start the year for the first time in a long time, but it's come in well above that for the first half of the year. Just kind of curious if you could talk about what's driven tha
componenttext: Michael, I want to ask you about the merch margin line. You guided it flat to start the year for the first time in a long time, but it's come in well above that for the first half of the year. Just kind of curious if you could talk about what's driven that upside, any specifics you can give? And then, how you're thinking about merch margin into the back half of the year?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ike. For the second quarter, as we mentioned, merchandise margin was up 35 basis points. It was really driven by a combination of better buying, but also when we're able to exceed our initial sales plan, there's markdown leverage and it helped us mo
componenttext:
Sure, Ike. For the second quarter, as we mentioned, merchandise margin was up 35 basis points. It was really driven by a combination of better buying, but also when we're able to exceed our initial sales plan, there's markdown leverage and it helped us move to drive the business with closeouts, so that was beneficial in the second quarter.
As we think about the third quarter, our current guidance assumes that merchandise margins are slightly lower, but that's because we're up against a 50 basis point increase from Q3 of last year.

Obviously, you guys did well, but I'm wondering if you had any comments on the promotional environment from some of your competitors.

componenttext: Sure. Although the inventory levels were down, the promotional environment continue to be very aggressive. And actually, we just considered that, that is the way to do business now, that, that is going to continue as we go forward through back-to-school and through holiday.

componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about marketing. How you guys are evolving your marketing strategies in this digital era? Are you using new techniques because the traffic and the comp trends are obviously quite excellent and counter to what's happening out there at the r
componenttext: I wanted to ask about marketing. How you guys are evolving your marketing strategies in this digital era? Are you using new techniques because the traffic and the comp trends are obviously quite excellent and counter to what's happening out there at the rest of the retail? I'm wondering if you can point to some new media strategies that might be working for you.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Omar, it's Michael O'Sullivan. I would say that our marketing strategy, marketing message, marketing programs remain fairly consistent. The message in those marketing programs is that we offer great values. And that's -- it's really the great values that,
componenttext:
Omar, it's Michael O'Sullivan. I would say that our marketing strategy, marketing message, marketing programs remain fairly consistent. The message in those marketing programs is that we offer great values. And that's -- it's really the great values that, I think, have driven our trend and will continue to drive our trend rather than the marketing programs.
Now, within your question, you mentioned sort of new marketing techniques. It is true. We're absolutely experimenting and expanding nontraditional forms of marketing, but I'd stop short of saying that those are really making a significant contribution to our trend. They're helpful, but that's not pretty much what's driving our business.

We'll comment more at the end of the year on our specific plans for 2018, but I think for planning purposes, you can assume that our store openings will be pretty much in line with where they've been the last couple of years. 80 to 90 new stores, approximately 20 to 25 of those being dd's and the rest being Ross. componenttextpreview: Sure, Laura. While we do face our most challenging prior year comparisons in Q3, it's clear to us that the consumer continues to favor retailers that offer compelling value. And we think that bodes well for us going into the third quarter.
componenttext: Sure, Laura. While we do face our most challenging prior year comparisons in Q3, it's clear to us that the consumer continues to favor retailers that offer compelling value. And we think that bodes well for us going into the third quarter.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Oliver Chen from Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Your next question is from Oliver Chen from Cowen and Company.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We had a question related to inventory. It's been extremely well-managed throughout the years. What are your thoughts for what's next? And it feels like your stores could even have more stuff and there's nice opportunities in new categories. So just a que
componenttext: We had a question related to inventory. It's been extremely well-managed throughout the years. What are your thoughts for what's next? And it feels like your stores could even have more stuff and there's nice opportunities in new categories. So just a question about different priorities with inventory management and what you can do to potentially even maximize the existing space you have? And then, longer-term, I was just curious about what's in your mindset in terms of your corporate strategies and what you're thinking about with digital at large over the next 5 years?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Oliver, on the inventory question, so we've gone through a period of 7 to 8 years of inventory reduction. Our total inventory is down over 40% over the last number of years. So as we look at it going forward, we're comfortable operating at our current lev
componenttext: Oliver, on the inventory question, so we've gone through a period of 7 to 8 years of inventory reduction. Our total inventory is down over 40% over the last number of years. So as we look at it going forward, we're comfortable operating at our current levels. That -- those reductions obviously have contributed to significant margin improvements, but we're in the very late innings of those reductions and are comfortable at the current levels.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And on your question about digital, Oliver, if I break it into, first of all, marketing, we are -- over the last 5 to 8 years, we've gone from building really nothing on sort of nontraditional digital marketing, so to speak, to a significant chunk of our
componenttext:
And on your question about digital, Oliver, if I break it into, first of all, marketing, we are -- over the last 5 to 8 years, we've gone from building really nothing on sort of nontraditional digital marketing, so to speak, to a significant chunk of our marketing budget now goes into those media. And we're pretty happy with the results. A lot of that space is still evolving, so I think we have additional things to learn, but I would be surprised if we didn't further increase our marketing mix in that direction over time.
And then, separately, I don't think it is what you're getting at, but separately, digital sort of e-commerce, we have no plans to pursue and we haven't changed our view. We have no plans to pursue e-commerce at this point.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. And are your inventories too lean because they're so tight? I'm just curious where you will reach a point where you can do more with more?
componenttext: Okay. And are your inventories too lean because they're so tight? I'm just curious where you will reach a point where you can do more with more?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We -- obviously, we watch very closely our inventory turns in the stores. And given our ability to continue to drive comp with a 4% comp in this past quarter on top of 4% last year, we feel pretty good. I think we're capturing the business that's out ther
componenttext:
We -- obviously, we watch very closely our inventory turns in the stores. And given our ability to continue to drive comp with a 4% comp in this past quarter on top of 4% last year, we feel pretty good. I think we're capturing the business that's out there.
Now, obviously there's always -- we always look at the mix of businesses and that some businesses are growing more rapidly and we might be more aggressive on inventory, but that's where it's business by business thing rather than overall.

And then, maybe some help on how to think about gross margin versus SG&A. Are you willing to take some more merchandise margin pressure than we've seen in recent quarters to help you anniversary that big comp?

componenttext: Yes, Michael. On the comp, if we think about the components between first and second quarter and our current trends in the second quarter, the performance was fairly broad, broad-based across merchandise divisions and regions. So we feel confident that the consumer is responding to value and we feel good about our inventory entering the third quarter.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And maybe I could ask you just a follow-up on Lorraine's question from earlier. A little bit more on the AUR. What is driving the AUR in your business today? Is it a mix function? And then, same question on what's -- you had some nice comments on the unit
componenttext: And maybe I could ask you just a follow-up on Lorraine's question from earlier. A little bit more on the AUR. What is driving the AUR in your business today? Is it a mix function? And then, same question on what's -- you had some nice comments on the units per transaction to -- what other categories that are helping you guys drive the consumer to pick up a couple extra items and growing the basket?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, on AUR, AUR has been relatively flat over the last several years. They're down slightly. Again, that's mix-related based on what's driving the business.I'd answer your question on the basket. If I go through the merchandising areas, all maj
componenttext:
Yes. I mean, on AUR, AUR has been relatively flat over the last several years. They're down slightly. Again, that's mix-related based on what's driving the business.
I'd answer your question on the basket. If I go through the merchandising areas, all major merchandising areas were positive during the quarter as well as merchandise region. We did call out shoes during the quarter. Overall, non-apparel, during the second quarter, outperformed apparel. So feel really good about the trends and believe we're set up well for a strong back half.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Mike, I think the merchants have been able to deliver value to the customers. So in this promotional environment where value moves a lot, one of the critical things is for a merchant to understand the value as they move and to respond appropriately. And s
componenttext: Mike, I think the merchants have been able to deliver value to the customers. So in this promotional environment where value moves a lot, one of the critical things is for a merchant to understand the value as they move and to respond appropriately. And so with that comes potentially mix issues based off of what's available, based off what the customer wants, but really understanding that movement of value as you move along and that really recognizing how promotional it is and how it's going to remain that way, I think, is a critical part of what merchants do everyday and has added to our broad-based success in merchandise categories in Q2.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I guess, my question is more -- you've seen the bogeyman, the 7-comp coming for a long time. You knew about it a year ago. So is it -- look, the strategy here is we know values working and the strategy for long time has been buy up per unit, so we'll see
componenttext: I guess, my question is more -- you've seen the bogeyman, the 7-comp coming for a long time. You knew about it a year ago. So is it -- look, the strategy here is we know values working and the strategy for long time has been buy up per unit, so we'll see if the traffic component of the comp is what accelerates in the 2-year to help you guys lap that. Is that what we should expect it to be?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, a couple of things, Michael. The -- our outlook for the back half has not changed from the beginning of the year. So again, why we feel really good, that's the way we plan the business. If you looked at our -- the way we guided the back half, it has
componenttext: Well, a couple of things, Michael. The -- our outlook for the back half has not changed from the beginning of the year. So again, why we feel really good, that's the way we plan the business. If you looked at our -- the way we guided the back half, it hasn't changed. The upside to the year was based on the outperformance in the second quarter. So the $0.06 that we added to the high end of the range for the year was all based on second quarter performance.

componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask, the third quarter comp guidance of plus 1% to 2%, is it fair to assume or could we assume that the business is running in that range so far here in the third quarter?And then, secondarily, it looks like there were a number of going out
componenttext:
I wanted to ask, the third quarter comp guidance of plus 1% to 2%, is it fair to assume or could we assume that the business is running in that range so far here in the third quarter?
And then, secondarily, it looks like there were a number of going out of business sales during the second quarter, particularly among department stores. I know the environment is tough and seems to be just getting tougher every year, but Ross seem to sail right on through that undisrupted. I just wanted to know if there was any disruption at all in stores that were near those store closings? Or did you really just not see it at all? Obviously, we're not seeing any impact in the total company comp, but you obviously have more granular insight.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Kimberly, we wouldn't comment on third quarter trends.On the store closures, what we're seeing is stores that are located close to the stores during liquidation has a slight negative impact and then post-closure, a slight positive impact. That said, the
componenttext:
Kimberly, we wouldn't comment on third quarter trends.
On the store closures, what we're seeing is stores that are located close to the stores during liquidation has a slight negative impact and then post-closure, a slight positive impact. That said, the impact to the chain is not material giving on a base of close to 1,600 stores.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: As you think about wages and shrink, any update on those 2 components and game plan for the second half of the year? And then, on dd's and that strong performance on sales and operating income, what are the key drivers there? And has anything changed in t
componenttext: As you think about wages and shrink, any update on those 2 components and game plan for the second half of the year? And then, on dd's and that strong performance on sales and operating income, what are the key drivers there? And has anything changed in that business?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure, Dana. On shrink and wage question, no changes are expected in shrink trends. We continue to operate at very low levels, record levels for us. And we typically take our physical inventory in the third quarter. So we'll have an update, if any change t
componenttext:
Sure, Dana. On shrink and wage question, no changes are expected in shrink trends. We continue to operate at very low levels, record levels for us. And we typically take our physical inventory in the third quarter. So we'll have an update, if any change to that trend, in Q3.
On wages, we do expect the wage pressure to abate somewhat in the second half as we're now anniversary-ing the most recent company-wide wage increases that took place in last year's second quarter. As a reminder, our guidance for SG&A, the leverage point remains at about 3% for us for the year.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And Dana, on your question about dd's, as Barbara mentioned in her remarks, we were pleased with dd's' strong performance in terms of sales and operating profit in the second quarter. dd's basically continued, as it has over the last several quarters, it'
componenttext:
And Dana, on your question about dd's, as Barbara mentioned in her remarks, we were pleased with dd's' strong performance in terms of sales and operating profit in the second quarter. dd's basically continued, as it has over the last several quarters, it's good results.
In terms of what's driving that, frankly, it's similar to many of the other things that we've talked about on this call so far. In particular, the dd's customer is responding well to the values that we're offering.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Lindsay Drucker Mann from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question is from Lindsay Drucker Mann from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017

componenttext:
I was hoping -- could you tell us what proportion of your sales come from credit cards?
And secondly, on the SG&A piece, well, the leverage point on a 4-comp, you leveraged operating margins pretty nicely. SG&A growth was lower than what we had seen in 1Q. And sorry if I missed this, but can you talk about the rate of SG&A increase in 2Q being lower versus 1Q and what we should be thinking about for the back half?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. On your question on credit, it's about 1/3 of our business, Lindsay.And then, on the SG&A leverage, as we mentioned in the call, we had 25 basis points of leverage on the 4-comp. 20 of that 25 was related to a nonrecurring legal matter. So baselin
componenttext:
Sure. On your question on credit, it's about 1/3 of our business, Lindsay.
And then, on the SG&A leverage, as we mentioned in the call, we had 25 basis points of leverage on the 4-comp. 20 of that 25 was related to a nonrecurring legal matter. So baseline, 5 basis points of leverage. As I mentioned on wages in the back half, we should expect less leverage. So at a one to 2-comp, there may be some deleverage, but at 3, we should get leverage.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. And then, can you comment on how your new stores are performing, new store productivity, proceeds of your new openings for Ross and dd's relative to what you've seen in last year or years past?
componenttext: Okay. Got it. And then, can you comment on how your new stores are performing, new store productivity, proceeds of your new openings for Ross and dd's relative to what you've seen in last year or years past?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. So as we mentioned in the past, our new store productivity has come down since we entered the midwest in 2011 and also our growth at dd's chain has impacted the overall productivity. I would say though in the last couple of years, it's been very ste
componenttext: Sure. So as we mentioned in the past, our new store productivity has come down since we entered the midwest in 2011 and also our growth at dd's chain has impacted the overall productivity. I would say though in the last couple of years, it's been very steady at or above our expectations. Overall, Ross new store is about 60% to 65% of the chain average and then tends to comp faster in the first couple of years.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017

componenttext: Your next question is from Brian Tunick from RBC.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I guess, 2 or 3 questions. Number one, I know you guys don't manage to a packaway number per se, but obviously there's been a lot of concern given what the vendors have been talking about. So just curious if you can maybe talk about the buying staff, what
componenttext:
I guess, 2 or 3 questions. Number one, I know you guys don't manage to a packaway number per se, but obviously there's been a lot of concern given what the vendors have been talking about. So just curious if you can maybe talk about the buying staff, what you've been doing there, maybe turnover in your top? I think [ someone ] has 10 vendors. But just curious more about how packaway could continue to run at these levels given what the vendors seem to be saying?
Second question would be maybe from a store growth runway and returns you're seeing on the new stores, at what point would you guys consider a new concept like Home, which seems to something people are moving into?
And then, thirdly, on freight contracts, Mike, just curious, what's the length of the contracts? And how is your best viewpoint going into next year?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I'll start on the last one because that's fairly different. On freight, we expect there to be a headwind for the rest of the year. Contracts vary. We have pretty good viewpoint for the rest of the year and we expect it to continue to be a headwind. And th
componenttext: I'll start on the last one because that's fairly different. On freight, we expect there to be a headwind for the rest of the year. Contracts vary. We have pretty good viewpoint for the rest of the year and we expect it to continue to be a headwind. And then, going into the next year, we'll talk more about that on the year-end conference call.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I'll take the second question and maybe Barbara will take the first. So we'll work in reverse order.So how long is store growth runway? The -- we've put out there a store potential number of 2,500 stores, and that's 2,000 Ross, 500 dd's. We're only at 1
componenttext:
I'll take the second question and maybe Barbara will take the first. So we'll work in reverse order.
So how long is store growth runway? The -- we've put out there a store potential number of 2,500 stores, and that's 2,000 Ross, 500 dd's. We're only at 1,500. So we've got many years to go before we hit that number.
You've mentioned Home specifically and moving into, I guess, the separate Home concept. We're very excited about Home. Our Home business has been one of our strongest performing businesses for a number of years, but we feel very happy with our ability to really go after that within our existing concepts and really sort of continue to grow that business within Ross and dd's rather than through a separate concept.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And as it pertains to packaway, the packaway number fluctuates based on availability in the market and the way the merchants see it. And there has been -- there's been plenty of branded bargains in the marketplace. So there is availability. I know there i
componenttext: And as it pertains to packaway, the packaway number fluctuates based on availability in the market and the way the merchants see it. And there has been -- there's been plenty of branded bargains in the marketplace. So there is availability. I know there isn't a lot of talk about different vendors having different strategies, but vendor strategies fluctuate over time and, net-net, is that there are a lot of goods in the marketplace and a lot of branded goods. And so we feel pretty good about the position that we're in and the content that we have.

componenttext:
Sure, Michael. So trends were steady during the quarter. May was slightly stronger than June and July, but -- which were similar.
In terms of buying cost, buying cost increased, as we mentioned, 15 basis points for the quarter, which mainly reflects higher incentive costs given our performance, but also ongoing investments that we continue to make in our most important asset, our buying organization.
