headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: As you think about wages and shrink, any update on those 2 components and game plan for the second half of the year? And then, on dd's and that strong performance on sales and operating income, what are the key drivers there? And has anything changed in t
componenttext: As you think about wages and shrink, any update on those 2 components and game plan for the second half of the year? And then, on dd's and that strong performance on sales and operating income, what are the key drivers there? And has anything changed in that business?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure, Dana. On shrink and wage question, no changes are expected in shrink trends. We continue to operate at very low levels, record levels for us. And we typically take our physical inventory in the third quarter. So we'll have an update if any change to
componenttext:
Sure, Dana. On shrink and wage question, no changes are expected in shrink trends. We continue to operate at very low levels, record levels for us. And we typically take our physical inventory in the third quarter. So we'll have an update if any change to that trend in Q3.
On wages, we do expect the wage pressure to abate somewhat in the second half as we're now anniversary-ing the most recent company-wide wage increases that took place in last year's second quarter. As a reminder, our guidance for SG&A, the leverage point remains at about 3% for us for the year.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And Dana, on your question about dd's, as Barbara mentioned in her remarks, we were pleased with dd's' strong performance in terms of sales and operating profit in the second quarter. dd's basically continued, as it has over the last several quarters, its
componenttext:
And Dana, on your question about dd's, as Barbara mentioned in her remarks, we were pleased with dd's' strong performance in terms of sales and operating profit in the second quarter. dd's basically continued, as it has over the last several quarters, its good results.
In terms of what's driving that, frankly, it's similar to many of the other things that we've talked about on this call so far. In particular, the dd's customer is responding well to the values that we're offering.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Lindsay Drucker Mann from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question is from Lindsay Drucker Mann from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I was hoping -- could you tell us what proportion of your sales come from credit cards?And secondly, on the SG&A piece, well, the leverage point on a 4-comp, you leveraged operating margins pretty nicely. SG&A growth was slower than what we had seen in
componenttext:
I was hoping -- could you tell us what proportion of your sales come from credit cards?
And secondly, on the SG&A piece, well, the leverage point on a 4-comp, you leveraged operating margins pretty nicely. SG&A growth was slower than what we had seen in 1Q. And sorry if I missed this, but can you talk about the rate of SG&A increase in 2Q being lower versus 1Q and what we should be thinking about for the back half?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. On your question on credit, it's about 1/3 of our business, Lindsay.And then, on the SG&A leverage, as we mentioned in the call, we had 25 basis points of leverage on a 4-comp. 20 of that 25 was related to a nonrecurring legal matter. So baseline,
componenttext:
Sure. On your question on credit, it's about 1/3 of our business, Lindsay.
And then, on the SG&A leverage, as we mentioned in the call, we had 25 basis points of leverage on a 4-comp. 20 of that 25 was related to a nonrecurring legal matter. So baseline, 5 basis points of leverage. As I mentioned on wages in the back half, we should expect less leverage. So at a 1- to 2-comp, there may be some deleverage, but at a 3, we should get leverage.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. And then, can you comment on how your new stores are performing, new store productivity, the productivity of your new openings for Ross and dd's relative to what you've seen in last year or years past?
componenttext: Okay. Got it. And then, can you comment on how your new stores are performing, new store productivity, the productivity of your new openings for Ross and dd's relative to what you've seen in last year or years past?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. So as we mentioned in the past, our new store productivity has come down since we entered the Midwest in 2011 and also our growth of the dd's chain has impacted overall productivity. I would say, though, in the last couple of years, it's been very s
componenttext: Sure. So as we mentioned in the past, our new store productivity has come down since we entered the Midwest in 2011 and also our growth of the dd's chain has impacted overall productivity. I would say, though, in the last couple of years, it's been very steady at or above our expectations. Overall, Ross new store is about 60% to 65% of the chain average and then tends to comp faster in the first couple of years.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Brian Tunick from RBC.
componenttext: Your next question is from Brian Tunick from RBC.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I guess, 2 or 3 questions. Number one, I know you guys don't manage to a packaway number per se, but obviously there's been a lot of concern given what the vendors have been talking about. So just curious if you can maybe talk about the buying staff, what
componenttext:
I guess, 2 or 3 questions. Number one, I know you guys don't manage to a packaway number per se, but obviously there's been a lot of concern given what the vendors have been talking about. So just curious if you can maybe talk about the buying staff, what you've been doing there, maybe turnover in your top, I think Simeon asked, 10 vendors. But just curious more about how packaway could continue to run at these levels given what the vendors seem to be saying?
Second question would be maybe from a store growth runway and the returns you're seeing on the new stores, at what point would you guys consider a new concept like Home, which seems to something people are moving into?
And then, thirdly, on freight contracts, Mike, just curious, what's the length of the contracts? And how is your best viewpoint going into next year?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I'll start on the last one because that's probably the easiest, Brian. On freight, we expect there to be a headwind for the rest of the year. Contracts vary. We have a pretty good viewpoint for the rest of the year and we expect it to continue to be a hea
componenttext: I'll start on the last one because that's probably the easiest, Brian. On freight, we expect there to be a headwind for the rest of the year. Contracts vary. We have a pretty good viewpoint for the rest of the year and we expect it to continue to be a headwind. And then, going into the next year, we'll talk more about that on the year-end conference call.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I'll take the second question and maybe Barbara will take the first. So we'll work in reverse order.So on the store growth runway, the -- we've put out there a store potential number of 2,500 stores, and that's 2,000 Ross, 500 dd's. We're only at 1,600.
componenttext:
I'll take the second question and maybe Barbara will take the first. So we'll work in reverse order.
So on the store growth runway, the -- we've put out there a store potential number of 2,500 stores, and that's 2,000 Ross, 500 dd's. We're only at 1,600. So we've got many years to go before we hit that number.
You've mentioned Home specifically and moving into, I guess, the separate Home concept. We're very excited about Home. Our Home business has been one of our strongest performing businesses for a number of years, but we feel very happy with our ability to really go after that within our existing concepts and really sort of continue to grow that business within Ross and dd's rather than through a separate concept.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And as it pertains to packaway, the packaway number fluctuates based on availability in the market and the way the merchants see it. And there have been -- there's been plenty of branded bargains in the marketplace. So there is availability. I know there
componenttext: And as it pertains to packaway, the packaway number fluctuates based on availability in the market and the way the merchants see it. And there have been -- there's been plenty of branded bargains in the marketplace. So there is availability. I know there isn't a lot of talk about different vendors having different strategies, but vendor strategies fluctuate over time and net-net is that there are a lot of goods in the marketplace and a lot of branded goods. And so we feel pretty good about the position that we're in and the content that we have.

componenttext:
Just 2 quick follow-ups that -- if I missed them, I apologize, but I don't think you talked about this. How about trend through the quarter by month? Anything to call out there?
And then, secondly, you said your buying costs were up. I'm just curious as to what happened there.

componenttextpreview: Sure, Michael. So trends were steady during the quarter. May was slightly stronger than June and July, but -- which were similar.In terms of buying costs, buying costs increased, as we mentioned, 15 basis points for the quarter, which mainly reflects hi
componenttext:
Sure, Michael. So trends were steady during the quarter. May was slightly stronger than June and July, but -- which were similar.
In terms of buying costs, buying costs increased, as we mentioned, 15 basis points for the quarter, which mainly reflects higher incentive costs given our performance, but also ongoing investments that we continue to make in our most important asset, our buying organization.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Ross Stores Third Quarter 2017 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Before we get started, on behalf of Ross Stores, I would like to note that the comments made on this call will contain forward-lo
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to the Ross Stores Third Quarter 2017 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] 
Before we get started, on behalf of Ross Stores, I would like to note that the comments made on this call will contain forward-looking statements regarding expectations about future growth and financial results, including sales and earnings forecasts and other matters that are based on the company's current forecast of aspects of its future business. These forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from historical performance or current expectations. Risk factors are included in today's press release and the company's fiscal 2016 Form 10-K and fiscal 2017 Form 10-Qs and 8-Ks on file with the SEC. 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Barbara Rentler, Chief Executive Officer.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Joining me on our call today are Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Executive Vice President, Finance and Legal; Michael Hartshorn, Group
componenttext:
Good afternoon. Joining me on our call today are Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Executive Vice President, Finance and Legal; Michael Hartshorn, Group Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Connie Kao, Vice President, Investor Relations. 
We'll begin our call today with a review of our third quarter and year-to-date performance, followed by our outlook for the remainder of the year. Afterwards, we'll be happy to respond to any questions you may have. 
As noted in today's press release, our third quarter sales and earnings outperformed our expectations despite being up against our toughest prior year comparison and 2 major hurricanes during the quarter. 
We are pleased with these results, which reflect our continued market share gains in a challenging retail environment. Earnings per share for the period were $0.72, up 16% from last year. These results include an approximate $0.01 benefit from favorable expense timing that's expected to reverse in the fourth quarter. 
Net earnings grew to $274 million compared to $204 million in the prior year. Sales for the third quarter rose 8% to $3.3 billion, with comparable store sales up 4% on top of a robust 7% gains last year. 
Operating margin of 13.3% was better than expected mainly due to a combination of higher merchandise margins and leverage on above-plan sales. 
For the first 9 months of fiscal 2017, earnings per share were $2.36, up 15% on top of an 11% increase in the prior year. Net earnings were $912 million, up from $817 million last year. Sales year-to-date rose 8% to $10.1 billion, with comparable store sales up 4% versus a 4% gain in the same period last year. 
By region, transfer fairly broad-based, with the Midwest performing the strongest during the period. We estimate that the hurricanes in Texas and Florida had a minimal impact for the quarter as sales rebounded significantly following the storms. 
By merchandise category, children's was the best-performing area, benefiting from solid execution of our merchandising strategies. 
Similar to Ross, dd's DISCOUNTS continue to post better-than-expected gains in both sales and operating profit for the third quarter. As we ended the third quarter, total consolidated inventories were up 4%, with average in-store inventories flat compared to the prior year. Packaway as a percent of total inventories was 46% compared to 45% last year. 
Turning to our expansion programs, we opened 30 new Ross and 10 dd's DISCOUNTS locations in third quarter, completing our 2017 store opening program. We expect to end the year with 1,408 Ross and 213 dd's DISCOUNTS stores and net increase of 88 locations for fiscal 2017. 
Now Michael Hartshorn will provide further color on our third quarter results and details on our guidance for the remainder of the year.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Barbara. Let's start with the third quarter results. Our 4% comparable store sales gain was driven by increases in both traffic and the size of the average basket. As Barbara mentioned, third quarter operating margin outperformed our projecti
componenttext:
Thank you, Barbara. Let's start with the third quarter results. Our 4% comparable store sales gain was driven by increases in both traffic and the size of the average basket. 
As Barbara mentioned, third quarter operating margin outperformed our projections and increased 65 basis points to 13.3%. Cost of goods sold for the quarter improved 30 basis points, driven by a 25 basis point increase in merchandise margin and occupancy and buying cost that were lower by 20 basis points each. These gains were partially offset by 30 basis point increase in freight cost, along with 5 basis points in higher distribution expenses due mainly to the timing of packaway-related costs. 
Selling, general and administrative expenses during the period were lower by 35 basis points as a result of leverage on our 4% comparable store sales gain, and as we anniversary nonrecurring cost in last year's third quarter. 
During the quarter, we repurchased 3.6 million shares of common stock for a total purchase price of $219 million. 
Year-to-date, we have bought back a total of 10.5 million shares for an aggregate price of $649 million. We remain on track to buy back a total of $875 million in stock for the year under the 2-year, $1.75 billion stock repurchase program approved by our Board of Directors in February of this year. 
Let's turn now to our fourth quarter outlook. As mentioned in our press release, we are raising our sales expectations for the fourth quarter. We now forecast comparable store sales to increase 2% to 3% on top of strong [indiscernible] over the last several years. We are projecting earnings per share to remain unchanged at $0.88 to $0.92 as the benefit from higher comparable store sales is expected to be offset by the aforementioned expense timing shift from the third to the fourth quarter. 
As a reminder, our EPS guidance for both the fourth quarter and fiscal year includes an estimated benefit of $0.08 from the extra week. 
The operating statement assumptions for our fourth quarter guidance include the following: Total sales are projected to grow 11% to 12%, which includes a benefit from this year's 53rd week; operating margin is projected to be in the range of 14.0% to 14.2% versus 13.6% in the prior year; net interest expense is estimated to be about $1.5 million; our tax rate is planned at approximately 37% to 38%, and we expect average diluted shares outstanding to be about 380 million. 
Based on our year-to-date results and projected fourth quarter guidance, we are now planning earnings per share for the full year on a 53-week basis to be in the range of $3.24 to $3.28. 
On a 52-week basis, this updated forecast for fiscal 2017 represents solid projected earnings per share growth of 12% to 13% on top of a 13% gain in 2016. 
Now I'll turn the call back to Barbara for closing comments.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. Again, we are pleased with the better-than-expected results we achieved in the third quarter despite facing our toughest prior year comparisons and 2 major hurricanes. As we enter the fourth quarter, we are encouraged by our above pl
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. Again, we are pleased with the better-than-expected results we achieved in the third quarter despite facing our toughest prior year comparisons and 2 major hurricanes. 
As we enter the fourth quarter, we are encouraged by our above planned sales and earnings year-to-date. In addition, our merchants have done an excellent job of acquiring exciting assortment of sharply priced name-brand fashions and guests to appeal to today's holiday shoppers. While we're optimistic about our prospects for the fourth quarter, our guidance reflects an uncertain external environment and the likelihood of yet another very promotional holiday season. 
As Michael just mentioned, we also faced our own challenging multi-year comparisons. Nonetheless, we believe that off-price will remain a strong performing segment in retail, driven by consumers ongoing focus on value. 
Most importantly, we have a consistent track record of being able to deliver the compelling bargains that our customers' desire. All of this makes us confident in our ability to achieve solid growth in sales and earnings over the long term. 
At this point, we'd like to open up the call and respond to any questions you might have.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question is from Simeon Siegel with Nomura Instinet.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question is from Simeon Siegel with Nomura Instinet.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: So with most companies calling out hurricane and warm weather impacts, can you just share any thoughts as to why you to really didn't see those pressures? And then just any way to think about operating expenses into next year, whether it's wage, freight o
componenttext: So with most companies calling out hurricane and warm weather impacts, can you just share any thoughts as to why you to really didn't see those pressures? And then just any way to think about operating expenses into next year, whether it's wage, freight or just anything else you have in mind.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure, it's Michael Hartshorn. On the hurricane impact, so we estimate that the negative impact of the hurricanes in Texas and Florida was less than 50 basis points the comp sales for the quarter. And to be clear, that estimate includes both the initial st
componenttext:
Sure, it's Michael Hartshorn. On the hurricane impact, so we estimate that the negative impact of the hurricanes in Texas and Florida was less than 50 basis points the comp sales for the quarter. And to be clear, that estimate includes both the initial store closures and a significant bounce back following the storms. About 15% of our stores were closed at some point during the storms, but all stores have reopened and all stores remained in our comp base throughout the quarter. 
In terms of other weather trends outside the hurricane impacts, weather was relatively neutral for us during the quarter.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Great. And then any thoughts on operating expenses?
componenttext: Great. And then any thoughts on operating expenses?

componenttext: Yes. So on operating expenses for next year, we wouldn't comment at this point, but in our year-end call, we'll update our guidance for the year.

componenttext: Your next question is from Matthew Boss from JPMorgan.

componenttext: Can you talk about your increased top line confidence entering the fourth quarter? And just anything you're seeing by category or execution opportunity versus last year? And if you drill down by region, could you just talk about new store performance in your Midwest builds? And anything in Texas post the hurricanes? Any kind of color would be great.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. In terms of the updated guidance in the fourth quarter as we mentioned in our comments, we're  encouraged by our above plan sales trends, not only the third quarter, but certainly, in the last six months. And our view that we're well positioned in t
componenttext: Sure. In terms of the updated guidance in the fourth quarter as we mentioned in our comments, we're  encouraged by our above plan sales trends, not only the third quarter, but certainly, in the last six months. And our view that we're well positioned in terms of the assortment and value offering for the holidays. In terms of regional performance, as we mentioned comments -- in our comments on the Midwest, it was the strongest performing region, and that's been the case since we entered the market in 2011, among other geographies, Texas actually performed above the chain average, with a significant sales rebound following Harvey. Obviously, that only impacted the Houston market or mainly impacted the Houston market. Florida was below the chain average, with most of the state impacted by Irma and California performed relatively in line with the chain average. Our new store credits -- go ahead. Sorry, Matt.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: No, no, go ahead. I was going to ask about the store productivity exactly.
componenttext: No, no, go ahead. I was going to ask about the store productivity exactly.

componenttext: So new store productivity, we've mentioned this on past calls, it come down over the last couple of years certainly with entry into the Midwest and also our dd's expansion, but that said, Midwest continues to be one of the strongest comping markets for us. Overall, Ross new stores are in the neighborhood of 60% to 65% of the chain average, with no material change this year.

componenttext: I guess, I was curious, Barbara, when you think about the biggest opportunities versus holiday last year, when you think about marketing or gifting or flow of goods, what do you think there are a couple of opportunities are? And then maybe, Michael, can talk a little bit about the comp composition. Should we expect at some point, do you think AUR can start to flatten out? Or is the model really driven by increases in traffic and the basket size?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brian. In terms of a product this year versus last year, what I would say is that our business is performing -- our performance is pretty broad-based right now. So we feel good as we enter into the fourth quarter that both our apparel and non-appare
componenttext: Sure, Brian. In terms of a product this year versus last year, what I would say is that our business is performing -- our performance is pretty broad-based right now. So we feel good as we enter into the fourth quarter that both our apparel and non-apparel businesses are working well. In terms of difference on the floor, why we say you'll see an expansion of gifts and I think in terms of values on the floor, there's been a lot of availability in the market, and we've had solid execution by the merchants all year. And that translates to good values in fashion on the floor in the fourth quarter.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: On the comp composition of the comp sales increase, Brian, as we've mentioned in prepared remarks, the 4% comp was driven by traffic and the size of the average basket. That basket was driven by increase in the units per transaction with AUR down slightly
componenttext: On the comp composition of the comp sales increase, Brian, as we've mentioned in prepared remarks, the 4% comp was driven by traffic and the size of the average basket. That basket was driven by increase in the units per transaction with AUR down slightly. Your questions specific to AUR, it's been relatively flat for a number of years. It is down slightly, but that's driven by the mix of the business.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I can just throw out one more. On the market share gains, you've been talking about so far this year, any changes in how your marketing in those store clusters? Or anything you're doing differently to capture those customers?
componenttext: Okay. And if I can just throw out one more. On the market share gains, you've been talking about so far this year, any changes in how your marketing in those store clusters? Or anything you're doing differently to capture those customers?

componenttextpreview: Brian, this is Michael O'Sullivan. The answer is no, not really. I mean, we are -- we continue to experiment in that marketing with new forms of marketing, but nothing that I would point to that really has driven our comp. What's been driving our comp is
componenttext: Brian, this is Michael O'Sullivan. The answer is no, not really. I mean, we are -- we continue to experiment in that marketing with new forms of marketing, but nothing that I would point to that really has driven our comp. What's been driving our comp is really the great values that are in the store. The marketing is reporting that, but it isn't what's driving it.

componenttext: Your next question is from Kimberly Greenberger with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Michael, I wanted to ask about SG&A. Obviously, you delivered very nice SG&A leverage here in the third quarter. It sounded like there was a $0.01 benefit to the third quarter from a shift, and you anniversaried, I think, some -- I think you said nonrecur
componenttext: Michael, I wanted to ask about SG&A. Obviously, you delivered very nice SG&A leverage here in the third quarter. It sounded like there was a $0.01 benefit to the third quarter from a shift, and you anniversaried, I think, some -- I think you said nonrecurring cost from last year. So on a normal go-forward basis on a 4% comp, let's say, I know you don't guide to four, but in the third quarter, you delivered a four, what sort of normal leverage would we expect to see out of SG&A? And then I'm wondering if you can talk to us about how you're thinking about any future impacts on SG&A from wage headwinds and how we should think about Ross navigating those wage headwinds?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. As we mentioned, the impact to the quarter as a reminder, last year in the third quarter, we did a 7 comp but only levered by 5 basis points. So that included a nonrecurring matter that helped our comparison this year. Going forward, the expectation
componenttext: Sure. As we mentioned, the impact to the quarter as a reminder, last year in the third quarter, we did a 7 comp but only levered by 5 basis points. So that included a nonrecurring matter that helped our comparison this year. Going forward, the expectation would be for us to have some leverage at that 3% comp level, that's kind of the breakeven. And looking into the fourth quarter, if we performed above the high end of the guidance, I think you should expect some leverage. In terms of wages, we're going through our budget right now, and we'll provide an update at year-end. But as we've always done, we'll look to mitigate any impact from wages by being more efficient in the business. Obviously, wages could also be positive for top line sales as well, so we'll update the group on our year-end call.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Omar Saad with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Your next question is from Omar Saad with Evercore ISI.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask a question about fashion and the fashion quotient, how do you think about the fashion quotient as you guys build inventory for holiday and into next year. And are there trends in the marketplace that you see are applicable across categorie
componenttext: I wanted to ask a question about fashion and the fashion quotient, how do you think about the fashion quotient as you guys build inventory for holiday and into next year. And are there trends in the marketplace that you see are applicable across categories that create consumer interest that we see opportunities? Just anything along those lines, how you're thinking about fashion in your product, that would be great.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. I would say that the aren't really any strong, strong fashion trends out there. I mean, there's some lower trends, but something that would be retain support of what you were doing going from a skinny jeans, to wide-legged pants. There's no major fa
componenttext: Sure. I would say that the aren't really any strong, strong fashion trends out there. I mean, there's some lower trends, but something that would be retain support of what you were doing going from a skinny jeans, to wide-legged pants. There's no major fashion trends. So I think that's part of the issue as you go through, particularly in ladies', apparel is that there aren't really any drivers out there. The trends that are out there, however, we have in our assortment, and because we've been able to execute at such a high level and liquidity, we've been able to take availability and get in season goods. And so we feel pretty good about our assortment as we enter into the fourth quarter, but I actually think a big part of the fashion quotient in the ladies' business is the lack of fashion to be honest.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017

componenttext: Got you. Well, you're definitely something really well with the plus 4 on a 7 [indiscernible].

componenttext: Sure. In terms of performance, the ladies' business performed slightly behind the chain average, and home performed slightly ahead of the chain average. componenttext: It's trend, and it's a combination of above plan performance so far. It sounds like it's been encouraging. The other question is about the non-apparel product mix. What's your framework for thinking about how to best utilize your square footage? You've done really good at managing for inventories, but it feels like there's a nice opportunity ahead as you evaluate what customers would want to buy from you in categories other than apparel.

componenttext: Oliver, in terms of the complexion of merchandise margin, it's been a mix of both the fine new and mark on and turning faster, and that's been true all year, and it was certainly true in the third quarter.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. And in terms of non-apparel in the product mix as it relates to the store, first, we've decide what businesses we want to drive and what trends we want to drive. In terms of utilizing square footage, since we set our inventory 40% over last 6 years
componenttext: Sure. And in terms of non-apparel in the product mix as it relates to the store, first, we've decide what businesses we want to drive and what trends we want to drive. In terms of utilizing square footage, since we set our inventory 40% over last 6 years or so, that space is an issue in terms of maximizing that space, we drive that base off of really what products we want to drive and put in front of the customer. We don't necessarily just say we want to build the space to say what is it you really want and can we deliver compelling bargains and then that's how we decide how we're going to spend the business.

componenttext: I wanted to talk a little bit about the drivers. The UPT that's headed higher, are you doing a better job on cash wrap, or do you have consumers buying a cross-category more than they did in the past? Or what's driving that? And then on the flip side, you said that AUR is lower because of mixed shift. Is that in any specific category. Are you seeing that trend across the store?

componenttextpreview: Laura, on UPT, we think it's just a function of putting great values in front of the customer. It's a product of the merchandise. So customers in, they're buying more per visit. And the second half of your question was on AUR. AUR is just down slightly, a
componenttext: Laura, on UPT, we think it's just a function of putting great values in front of the customer. It's a product of the merchandise. So customers in, they're buying more per visit. And the second half of your question was on AUR. AUR is just down slightly, and it's mixed within mixes of business, so it's not a fundamental change for us.

componenttextpreview: Just wondering if in terms of the comp performance, do you feel like you've had significant benefit from competitive store closures throughout retail? And on the children's business, can you elaborate on what you saw in children's and what led that to be
componenttext: Just wondering if in terms of the comp performance, do you feel like you've had significant benefit from competitive store closures throughout retail? And on the children's business, can you elaborate on what you saw in children's and what led that to be such a successful category this quarter?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: On the store closures, no, there's not a significant benefit. The number of stores is not only not material, it impacts about 10% of the chain. But the pickup post-liquidation is not meaningful to the overall comp.
componenttext: On the store closures, no, there's not a significant benefit. The number of stores is not only not material, it impacts about 10% of the chain. But the pickup post-liquidation is not meaningful to the overall comp.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: And in terms of the Kid's business, the performance is broad-based so it was every segment, infant, boys, girls. And we've had really solid execution in there. And so we were able to chase a lot of that business and offer compelling bargains to the custom
componenttext: And in terms of the Kid's business, the performance is broad-based so it was every segment, infant, boys, girls. And we've had really solid execution in there. And so we were able to chase a lot of that business and offer compelling bargains to the customer.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Great. And on dd's, are you seeing success in similar categories that you're seeing at Ross? Or is there a big difference from the merchandising mix there?
componenttext: Great. And on dd's, are you seeing success in similar categories that you're seeing at Ross? Or is there a big difference from the merchandising mix there?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: As Barbara said in her remarks, dd's posted pretty good sales and operating profit in the quarter. I would say that, as you know, dd's has a somewhat different customer segment. But in many ways, the same factors that drove Ross' success, that also play a
componenttext: As Barbara said in her remarks, dd's posted pretty good sales and operating profit in the quarter. I would say that, as you know, dd's has a somewhat different customer segment. But in many ways, the same factors that drove Ross' success, that also play at dd's. There's a focus on value, the ability to offer great bargains through opportunistic buying but very strong execution of our merchandising and operating strategies. Those things factor apply at dd's. But the specifics in terms of what are the merchandising strategies, difference, obviously, between dd's and Ross. But the overall drivers, I would say, are very similar.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017

componenttext: Your next question is from Roxanne Meyer with MKM Partners.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: My question is on your packaway business. It's been a fairly consistent percentage. But I'm just wondering in light of the continued market availability and the trends that you've been seeing, the fact that you've been chasing business, I'm wondering if y
componenttext: My question is on your packaway business. It's been a fairly consistent percentage. But I'm just wondering in light of the continued market availability and the trends that you've been seeing, the fact that you've been chasing business, I'm wondering if you're thinking longer term about scaling that business down or changing the way that you buy overtime?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: So the way we think about packaway is if there's -- there's no definitive number we go out there thinking about it. We do it based off what the merchandise offered us the is for us. So if it's a great deal, we buy it. And so that oftentimes built to the n
componenttext: So the way we think about packaway is if there's -- there's no definitive number we go out there thinking about it. We do it based off what the merchandise offered us the is for us. So if it's a great deal, we buy it. And so that oftentimes built to the number that you get to. You're trying to get to if we're chasing business for packaway because sometimes there are compelling bargains of seasonal goods. So if it's weather throughout our expected he want to fact that the way because you can do so to open the season and to drive sales until you get more availability in the marketplace. So we feel good about packaway, and we feel very good about the content of the packaway that we have right now.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Jamie with Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question is from Jamie with Bernstein.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: My question is just a follow-up on self productivity. As you build awareness and market share in the Midwest, would you expectation be that, that new store productivity should start to come up over time? And can you just talk about for your more mature st
componenttext: My question is just a follow-up on self productivity. As you build awareness and market share in the Midwest, would you expectation be that, that new store productivity should start to come up over time? And can you just talk about for your more mature stores in the Midwest, are you seeing sales productivity at chain average levels?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. Certainly, we would see stores after they open given the comp that their average in-store volumes are increasing. Right now, we're planning the business as if the productivity would be lower in year one and then comp faster in the first couple years
componenttext: Sure. Certainly, we would see stores after they open given the comp that their average in-store volumes are increasing. Right now, we're planning the business as if the productivity would be lower in year one and then comp faster in the first couple years. It's unlikely that it would reach the chain average and there would be in regions for 30 years in California, which are our most productive stores. But we would expect them to continue to grow over time for sure.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Mike Baker with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question is from Mike Baker with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: May be a 2-part question. One on dd's, is it yet or what point does it become big enough to impact the comp? In other words, does the Ross only store comp reflect the total company's comp? Or at some point, is dd's sort of dragging up the entire comp as i
componenttext: May be a 2-part question. One on dd's, is it yet or what point does it become big enough to impact the comp? In other words, does the Ross only store comp reflect the total company's comp? Or at some point, is dd's sort of dragging up the entire comp as it becomes bigger?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Mike, at this point, dd's represents less than 10% of the business. So just mathematically, the key driver of the corporations comp is relative comp.
componenttext: Yes. So Mike, at this point, dd's represents less than 10% of the business. So just mathematically, the key driver of the corporations comp is relative comp.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Understood. But at 10% of the business, if it were less mature in comping up 500 basis points better, that could sort of lift total comps by 50 basis points and be the difference between the way you guys pour it a whole number. So, in other words, just tr
componenttext: Understood. But at 10% of the business, if it were less mature in comping up 500 basis points better, that could sort of lift total comps by 50 basis points and be the difference between the way you guys pour it a whole number. So, in other words, just trying to see if decor stores are comping in line with what you're reporting for the total company. And I guess, it sounds like they are. May be a follow-up question, is there any big differential based on the maturity of store? I guess, you said California, which I presume are the most mature stores are in line with the chain average, but maybe if you look at 5-year old stores versus 10-year old stores versus 15-year-old stores, et cetera do the comps fall off as you go out further?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say the difference on conference really in the first 5 years. After 5 years, there is not a meaningful break. Again, I used California as an example because we've been in there for 30 years and the vast majority of those stores we've been in 10,
componenttext: Yes, I'd say the difference on conference really in the first 5 years. After 5 years, there is not a meaningful break. Again, I used California as an example because we've been in there for 30 years and the vast majority of those stores we've been in 10, 15 years and there's no break -- there's no lack of confidence in the stores. So the real difference was the first 5 years.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Lindsay Drucker Mann with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question is from Lindsay Drucker Mann with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: I had a follow-up question for Michael on your comments that inventories had been turning faster all year, and that's helped your merchandise margin. I was curious what the key driver was of that accelerated inventory turn, whether it's related to maybe n
componenttext: I had a follow-up question for Michael on your comments that inventories had been turning faster all year, and that's helped your merchandise margin. I was curious what the key driver was of that accelerated inventory turn, whether it's related to maybe new systems or processes or a product mix. What explains it? And is there more left to go there for next year, where we can expect inventory turns to be faster again?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure, Lindsay. So first, inventory has been down over 40% over a number of years. This year, it's strictly a function of how we're executing the business in open-to-buy. We go into the year with a 1 to 2 comp. We plan inventories at that level. If we can
componenttext: Sure, Lindsay. So first, inventory has been down over 40% over a number of years. This year, it's strictly a function of how we're executing the business in open-to-buy. We go into the year with a 1 to 2 comp. We plan inventories at that level. If we can exceed that comp, you're able to chase the business and you turn faster. So this year, it's really a function of how we manage the business. And I think that's going to be the opportunity going forward as well in terms of when we look into next year and beyond.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Got it. And one for Barbara, you highlighted in your opening remarks that you're braced for a very promotional holiday. Holidays are often very promotional. I'm curious if you think there's anything different about sort of how you think this holiday seaso
componenttext: Got it. And one for Barbara, you highlighted in your opening remarks that you're braced for a very promotional holiday. Holidays are often very promotional. I'm curious if you think there's anything different about sort of how you think this holiday season might play out or dynamics that you think might allow it to shape up differently than other kind of promotional seasons in the past.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, it's been promotional all year. What I really think is that it will be more promotional. It's already started to be promotional. We are starting earlier, and then that last-minute push up at the very end, our expectation is that it will be more prom
componenttext: Well, it's been promotional all year. What I really think is that it will be more promotional. It's already started to be promotional. We are starting earlier, and then that last-minute push up at the very end, our expectation is that it will be more promotional than it was last year as hard as that is to believe, but I do believe that. And so we're trying to foster ourselves understanding that, that's what that looks like.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017

componenttext: There are no further questions at this time. I will turn the call back over to Barbara Rentler for closing remarks.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Ross Stores Third Quarter 2017 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Before we get started, on behalf of Ross Stores, I would like to note that the comments made on this call will contain forward-lo
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to the Ross Stores Third Quarter 2017 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] 
Before we get started, on behalf of Ross Stores, I would like to note that the comments made on this call will contain forward-looking statements regarding expectations about future growth and financial results, including sales and earnings forecasts and other matters that are based on the company's current forecast of aspects of its future business. These forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from historical performance or current expectations. Risk factors are included in today's press release and the company's fiscal 2016 Form 10-K and fiscal 2017 Form 10-Qs and 8-Ks on file with the SEC. 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Barbara Rentler, Chief Executive Officer.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Joining me on our call today are Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Executive Vice President, Finance and Legal; Michael Hartshorn, Group
componenttext:
Good afternoon. Joining me on our call today are Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Executive Vice President, Finance and Legal; Michael Hartshorn, Group Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Connie Kao, Vice President, Investor Relations. 
We'll begin our call today with a review of our third quarter and year-to-date performance, followed by our outlook for the remainder of the year. Afterwards, we'll be happy to respond to any questions you may have. 
As noted in today's press release, our third quarter sales and earnings outperformed our expectations despite being up against our toughest prior year comparison and 2 major hurricanes during the quarter. We are pleased with these results, which reflect our continued market share gains in a challenging retail environment. 
Earnings per share for the period were $0.72, up 16% from last year. These results include an approximate $0.01 benefit from favorable expense timing that's expected to reverse in the fourth quarter. 
Net earnings grew to $274 million compared to $204 million in the prior year. Sales for the third quarter rose 8% to $3.3 billion with comparable store sales up 4% on top of a robust 7% gains last year. 
Operating margin of 13.3% was better than expected, mainly due to a combination of higher merchandise margins and leverage on above-plan sales.
For the first 9 months of fiscal 2017, earnings per share were $2.36, up 15% on top of an 11% increase in the prior year. Net earnings were $912 million, up from $817 million last year. Sales year-to-date rose 8% to $10.1 billion with comparable store sales up 4% versus a 4% gain in the same period last year. 
By region, trends were fairly broad-based with the Midwest performing the strongest during the period. We estimate that the hurricanes in Texas and Florida had a minimal impact for the quarter as sales rebounded significantly following the storms. 
By merchandise category, children's was the best-performing area, benefiting from solid execution of our merchandising strategies. 
Similar to Ross, dd's DISCOUNTS continued to post better-than-expected gains in both sales and operating profit for the third quarter. As we ended the third quarter, total consolidated inventories were up 4%, with average in-store inventories flat compared to the prior year. Packaway as a percent of total inventories was 46% compared to 45% last year. 
Turning to our expansion programs, we opened 30 new Ross and 10 dd's DISCOUNT locations in third quarter, completing our 2017 store opening program. We expect to end the year with 1,408 Ross and 213 dd's DISCOUNTS stores, a net increase of 88 locations for fiscal 2017. 
Now Michael Hartshorn will provide further color on our third quarter results and details on our guidance for the remainder of the year.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Barbara. Let's start with our third quarter results. Our 4% comparable store sales gain was driven by increases in both traffic and the size of the average basket. As Barbara mentioned, third quarter operating margin outperformed our projection
componenttext:
Thank you, Barbara. Let's start with our third quarter results. Our 4% comparable store sales gain was driven by increases in both traffic and the size of the average basket. As Barbara mentioned, third quarter operating margin outperformed our projections and increased 65 basis points to 13.3%. 
Cost of goods sold for the quarter improved 30 basis points, driven by a 25 basis point increase in merchandise margin and occupancy and buying cost that were lower by 20 basis points each. These gains were partially offset by 30 basis point increase in freight cost, along with 5 basis points in higher distribution expenses due mainly to the timing of packaway-related costs. 
Selling, general and administrative expenses during the period were lower by 35 basis points as a result of leverage on our 4% comparable store sales gain and as we anniversary-ed nonrecurring cost in last year's third quarter. 
During the quarter, we repurchased 3.6 million shares of common stock for a total purchase price of $219 million. Year-to-date, we have bought back a total of 10.5 million shares for an aggregate price of $649 million. We remain on track to buy back a total of $875 million in stock for the year under the 2-year, $1.75 billion stock repurchase program approved by our Board of Directors in February of this year. 
Let's turn now to our fourth quarter outlook. As mentioned in our press release, we are raising our sales expectations for the fourth quarter. We now forecast comparable store sales to increase 2% to 3% on top of strong [Audio Gap] over the last several years. We are projecting earnings per share to remain unchanged at $0.88 to $0.92, as the benefit from higher comparable store sales is expected to be offset by the aforementioned expense timing shift from the third to the fourth quarter. As a reminder, our EPS guidance for both the fourth quarter and fiscal year includes an estimated benefit of $0.08 from the extra week. 
The operating statement assumptions for our fourth quarter guidance include the following: total sales are projected to grow 11% to 12%, which includes a benefit from this year's 53rd week; operating margin is projected to be in the range of 14.0% to 14.2% versus 13.6% in the prior year; net interest expense is estimated to be about $1.5 million; our tax rate is planned at approximately 37% to 38%; and we expect average diluted shares outstanding to be about 380 million. 
Based on our year-to-date results and projected fourth quarter guidance, we are now planning earnings per share for the full year on a 53-week basis to be in the range of $3.24 to $3.28. On a 52-week basis, this updated forecast for fiscal 2017 represents solid projected earnings per share growth of 12% to 13% on top of a 13% gain in 2016. 
Now I'll turn the call back to Barbara for closing comments.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. Again, we are pleased with the better-than-expected results we achieved in the third quarter despite facing our toughest prior year comparisons and 2 major hurricanes. As we enter the fourth quarter, we are encouraged by our above-pl
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. Again, we are pleased with the better-than-expected results we achieved in the third quarter despite facing our toughest prior year comparisons and 2 major hurricanes. 
As we enter the fourth quarter, we are encouraged by our above-plan sales and earnings year-to-date. In addition, our merchants have done an excellent job of acquiring exciting assortment of sharply priced name-brand fashions and guests to appeal to today's holiday shoppers. While we're optimistic about our prospects for the fourth quarter, our guidance reflects an uncertain external environment and the likelihood of yet another very promotional holiday season. As Michael just mentioned, we also faced our own challenging multiyear comparisons. Nonetheless, we believe that off-price will remain a strong performing segment in retail, driven by consumers' ongoing focus on value. 
Most importantly, we have a consistent track record of being able to deliver the compelling bargains that our customers desire. All of this makes us confident in our ability to achieve solid growth in sales and earnings over the long term. 
At this point, we'd like to open up the call and respond to any questions you might have.

On the hurricane impact, so we estimate that the negative impact of the hurricanes in Texas and Florida was less than 50 basis points, the comp sales for the quarter end. To be clear, that estimate includes both the initial store closures and a significant bounce back following the storms. About 15% of our stores were closed at some point during the storms, but all stores have reopened and all stores remained in our comp base throughout the quarter. In terms of other weather trends outside the hurricane impacts, weather was relatively neutral for us during the quarter.

In terms of the updated guidance in the fourth quarter, as we mentioned in our comments, we're  encouraged by our above-plan sales trends, not only in the third quarter, but certainly in the last six months. And our view that we're well positioned in terms of assortment and value offering for the holidays. In terms of regional performance, as we mentioned, comments -- in our comments on the Midwest, it was the strongest performing region, and that's been the case since we entered the market in 2011 among our other geographies. Texas actually performed above the chain average with the significant sales rebound following Harvey. Obviously, that only impacted the Houston market or mainly impacted the Houston market. Florida was below the chain average with most of the state impacted by Irma, and California performed relatively in line with the chain average. Our new store credits -- go ahead. Sorry, Matt.

componenttext: Michael, I wanted to ask about SG&A. Obviously, you delivered very nice SG&A leverage here in the third quarter. It sounded like there was a $0.01 benefit to the third quarter from a shift and you anniversary-ed, I think, some -- I think you said nonrecurring cost from last year. So on a normal go-forward basis on a 4% comp, let's say, I know you don't guide to 4%, but in the third quarter, you delivered a 4%, what sort of normal leverage would we expect to see out of SG&A? And then I'm wondering if you can talk to us about how you're thinking about any future impacts on SG&A from wage headwinds and how we should think about Ross navigating those wage headwinds?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. As we mentioned, the impact to the quarter as a reminder, last year in the third quarter, we did a 7 comp, but only levered by 5 basis points. So that included a nonrecurring matter that helped our comparison this year. Going forward, the expectatio
componenttext: Sure. As we mentioned, the impact to the quarter as a reminder, last year in the third quarter, we did a 7 comp, but only levered by 5 basis points. So that included a nonrecurring matter that helped our comparison this year. Going forward, the expectation would be for us to have some leverage at the 3% comp level, that's kind of the breakeven. And looking into the fourth quarter, if we performed above the high end of the guidance, I think you should expect some leverage. In terms of wages, we're going through our budget right now and we'll provide an update at year-end. But as we've always done, we'll look to mitigate any impact from wages by being more efficient in the business. Obviously, wages could also be positive for top line sales as well. So we'll update the group on our year-end call.

componenttextpreview: Sure. I would say that they aren't really any strong, strong fashion trends out there. I mean, there's some smaller trends, but something that would be -- would change the course of what you were doing going from a skinny jeans to a wide-legged pants. The
componenttext: Sure. I would say that they aren't really any strong, strong fashion trends out there. I mean, there's some smaller trends, but something that would be -- would change the course of what you were doing going from a skinny jeans to a wide-legged pants. There's no major fashion trend. So I think that's part of the issue as you go through, particularly in Ladies Apparel is that there aren't any real drivers out there. The trends that are out there, however, we have in our assortment. And because we've been able to execute at such a high level and have liquidity, we've been able to chase availability and get in-season goods. And so we feel pretty good about our assortment as we enter into the fourth quarter, but I actually think a big part of the fashion quotient in the Ladies business is the lack of fashion to be honest.

componenttext: Just wondering if in terms of the comp performance, do you feel like you've had significant benefit from competitive store closures throughout retail? And on the children's business, can you just elaborate on what you saw in children's and what led that to be such a successful category this quarter?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: On the store closures, no, there's not a significant benefit. There's -- the number of stores is not only not material, it impacts about 10% of the chain. But the pickup post liquidation is not meaningful to the overall comp.
componenttext: On the store closures, no, there's not a significant benefit. There's -- the number of stores is not only not material, it impacts about 10% of the chain. But the pickup post liquidation is not meaningful to the overall comp.

componenttextpreview: And in terms of the Kid's business, the performance is broad-based. So it was every segment, infant, boys, girls, and we've had really solid execution in there. And so we were able to chase a lot of that business and offer compelling bargains to the custo
componenttext: And in terms of the Kid's business, the performance is broad-based. So it was every segment, infant, boys, girls, and we've had really solid execution in there. And so we were able to chase a lot of that business and offer compelling bargains to the customer.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Great. And on dd's, are you seeing success in similar categories that you're seeing at Ross? Or is there a big difference from the merchandising mix there?
componenttext: Great. And on dd's, are you seeing success in similar categories that you're seeing at Ross? Or is there a big difference from the merchandising mix there?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, as Barbara said in her remarks, dd's posted pretty good sales and operating profit in the quarter. I would say that, as you know, dd's has a somewhat different customer segment. But in many ways, the same factors that drove Ross' success, they'
componenttext: Well, yes, as Barbara said in her remarks, dd's posted pretty good sales and operating profit in the quarter. I would say that, as you know, dd's has a somewhat different customer segment. But in many ways, the same factors that drove Ross' success, they're also at play at dd's. That's the focus on value, the ability to offer great bargains through opportunistic buying, but very strong execution of our merchandising and operating strategies. Those same factors apply at dd's. But the specifics in terms of what are the merchandising strategies are different, obviously, between dd's and Ross. But the overall drivers, I would say, are very similar.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: My question is on your packaway business, it's been a fairly consistent percentage. But I'm just wondering in light of the continued market availability and the trends that you've been seeing, the fact that you've been chasing business, I'm wondering if y
componenttext: My question is on your packaway business, it's been a fairly consistent percentage. But I'm just wondering in light of the continued market availability and the trends that you've been seeing, the fact that you've been chasing business, I'm wondering if you're thinking longer term about scaling that business down or changing the way that you buy over time.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, the way we think about packaway is if there's -- there's no definitive number we go out there thinking about it with. We really do it based off of what the merchandise has offered out there is for us. So if it's great deal, we buy it. And so that, o
componenttext: Well, the way we think about packaway is if there's -- there's no definitive number we go out there thinking about it with. We really do it based off of what the merchandise has offered out there is for us. So if it's great deal, we buy it. And so that, oftentimes, build to the number of that, that you get to. You're trying to get to if we're chasing business for packaway because sometimes there are compelling bargains of seasonal goods. So if it's sweaters or outdoor or things like that, you want to pack that away because you can use those to open the season and to drive sales until you get more availability in the marketplace. So we feel good about packaway, and we feel good -- very good about the contents of the packaway that we have right now.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: My question is just a follow-up on self-productivity. As you build awareness and market share in the Midwest, would your expectation be that, that new store productivity should start to come up over time? And can you just talk about for your more mature s
componenttext: My question is just a follow-up on self-productivity. As you build awareness and market share in the Midwest, would your expectation be that, that new store productivity should start to come up over time? And can you just talk about for your more mature stores in the Midwest, are you seeing sales productivity at chain average levels?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. Certainly, we would see stores after they open given the comp that their average store volumes are increasing. Right now, we're planning the business as if the productivity would be lower in year 1 and then comp faster in the first couple years. It'
componenttext: Sure. Certainly, we would see stores after they open given the comp that their average store volumes are increasing. Right now, we're planning the business as if the productivity would be lower in year 1 and then comp faster in the first couple years. It's unlikely that it would reach the chain average and we have been in regions for 30 years in California, which are our most productive stores. But we would expect them to continue to grow over time for sure.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017

componenttext: Maybe a two-part question. One on dd's, is it yet -- or what point does it become big enough to impact the comp? In other words, does the Ross-only stores comp reflects the total company comp? Or at some point, is dd's sort of dragging up the entire comp as it becomes bigger?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Mike, at this point, dd's represents less than 10% of the business. So just mathematically, the key driver of the corporation's comp is relative comp.
componenttext: Yes. So Mike, at this point, dd's represents less than 10% of the business. So just mathematically, the key driver of the corporation's comp is relative comp.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Understood. But if at 10% of the business, if it were less mature in comping up 500 basis points better, that could sort of lift total comps by 50 basis points and be the difference between the way you guys pour a whole number. So in other words, just try
componenttext: Understood. But if at 10% of the business, if it were less mature in comping up 500 basis points better, that could sort of lift total comps by 50 basis points and be the difference between the way you guys pour a whole number. So in other words, just trying to see if the core stores are comping in line with what you're reporting for the total company. And I guess, it sounds like they are. Maybe a follow-up question, is there any big differential based on the maturity of stores? I guess, you said California, which I presume are the most mature stores or in line with the chain average. But maybe if you look at 5-year-old stores versus 10-year-old stores versus 15-year-old stores, et cetera, do the comps fall off as you go out further?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say the difference on comp is really in the first 5 years. After 5 years, there's not a meaningful break. Again, I used California as an example. We've been in there for 30 years. And the vast majority of those stores we've been in, 10, 15 years,
componenttext: Yes, I'd say the difference on comp is really in the first 5 years. After 5 years, there's not a meaningful break. Again, I used California as an example. We've been in there for 30 years. And the vast majority of those stores we've been in, 10, 15 years, and there's no break and there's no lack of confidence in the stores. So the real difference was the first 5 years.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: I had a follow-up question for Michael on your comment that inventory has been turning faster all year and that's helped your merchandise margin. I was curious what the key driver was of that accelerated inventory turn, whether it's related to maybe new s
componenttext: I had a follow-up question for Michael on your comment that inventory has been turning faster all year and that's helped your merchandise margin. I was curious what the key driver was of that accelerated inventory turn, whether it's related to maybe new systems or processes or a product mix. What explains it? And is there more left to go there for next year where we can expect inventory turns to be faster again?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure, Lindsay. So first, inventories had been down over 40% over a number of years. This year, it's strictly a function of how we're executing the business in open-to-buy. We go into the year with a 1 to 2 comp. We plan inventories at that level. If we ca
componenttext: Sure, Lindsay. So first, inventories had been down over 40% over a number of years. This year, it's strictly a function of how we're executing the business in open-to-buy. We go into the year with a 1 to 2 comp. We plan inventories at that level. If we can exceed that comp, you're able to chase the business and you turn faster. So this year, it's really a function of how we manage the business, and I think that's going to be the opportunity going forward as well in terms of when we look into next year and beyond.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Got it. And one for Barbara, you highlighted in your opening remarks that you're braced for a very promotional holiday. Holidays are often very promotional. I'm curious if you think there's anything different about sort of how you think this holiday seaso
componenttext: Got it. And one for Barbara, you highlighted in your opening remarks that you're braced for a very promotional holiday. Holidays are often very promotional. I'm curious if you think there's anything different about sort of how you think this holiday season might play out or dynamics that you think might allow it to shape up differently than other kind of promotional seasons in the past.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, it's been promotional all year. What I really think is that it will be more promotional. It's already started to be promotional. We are starting earlier, and then that last-minute push up at the very end, our expectation is that it will be more prom
componenttext: Well, it's been promotional all year. What I really think is that it will be more promotional. It's already started to be promotional. We are starting earlier, and then that last-minute push up at the very end, our expectation is that it will be more promotional than it was last year as far as that is to believe, but I do believe that. And so we're trying to pause ourselves, understanding that that's what that looks like.
